docs.snippet: Qatar Petroleum wants to export American gas by converting the terminal to export from import at a cost of at least $10 billion.
docs.lead_paragraph: Qatar Petroleum wants to export American gas by converting the terminal to export from import at a cost of at least $10 billion.
docs.abstract: Qatar Petroleum wants to export American natural gas by converting giant Golden Pass terminal in Sabine Pass, Tex, to export from import at a cost of at least $10 billion; is partnering with Exxon Mobile in effort to export sizable share of the new American bonanza.

headline.main: A U-Turn for a Terminal Built in Texas to Import Natural Gas
headline.print_headline: A U-Turn for a Terminal Built to Import Natural Gas

docs.snippet: Representative Frank R. Wolf wrote a letter to the Brookings Institution this week saying that think tanks that provide Congress with policy advice should refrain from taking donations from some foreign governments.
docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Frank R. Wolf wrote a letter to the Brookings Institution this week saying that think tanks that provide Congress with policy advice should refrain from taking donations from some foreign governments.
docs.abstract: Rep Frank R Wolf, Republican of Virginia, writes letter to president of Brookings Institution saying that prominent Washington think tanks that routinely provide Congress with policy advice should refrain from taking foreign government donations; Brookings collects about 12 percent of its annual budget from foreign governments.

headline.main: Lawmaker Assails Foreign Donations to Think Tanks
headline.print_headline: Lawmaker Assails Foreign Giving to Think Tanks

docs.snippet: Prominent Washington think tanks, nonprofits known for their impartiality, have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect the donors’...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prominent Washington think tanks, nonprofits known for their impartiality, have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect the donors’ priorities, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
docs.abstract: New York Times investigation finds that more than dozen prominent Washington research groups have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments in recent years while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect donors' priorities; money is increasingly transforming once-staid think-tank world into muscular arm of foreign governments' lobbying in Washington.

headline.main: Foreign Powers Buy Influence at Think Tanks
headline.print_headline: Foreign Powers Buy Influence at Think Tanks

keywords.value: Center for Strategic and International Studies
keywords.name: organizations

byline.original: By ERIC LIPTON, BROOKE WILLIAMS and NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

docs.snippet: While partners like Sony and Adidas raised concerns before the World Cup, it is unlikely that sponsor companies will risk undermining their investment in the FIFA brand.
docs.lead_paragraph: While partners like Sony and Adidas raised concerns before the World Cup, it is unlikely that sponsor companies will risk undermining their investment in the FIFA brand.
docs.abstract: Corporate sponsors of FIFA like Sony and Adidas raised concerns about accusations of corruption before 2014 World Cup began in June, but now that soccer matches are over, it is unlikely that they will demand reforms and risk undermining their big investments in FIFA brand.

headline.main: With Huge Sums in Play, FIFA Sponsors Are Reluctant to Push Reforms
headline.print_headline: With Huge Sums in Play, FIFA Sponsors Are Reluctant to Push Reforms

docs.snippet: Qatar has helped support a spectrum of Islamist groups by providing safe haven, diplomatic mediation, financial aid and, in certain instances, weapons.
docs.lead_paragraph: Qatar has helped support a spectrum of Islamist groups by providing safe haven, diplomatic mediation, financial aid and, in certain instances, weapons.
docs.abstract: Qatar has come under withering attack from wide spectrum of interests who insist that tiny monarchy is a godfather to terrorist causes worldwide; country has helped support a number of Islamist groups by providing safe haven, diplomatic mediation, financial aid and even weapons, and allows private fund-raisers for terrorist organizations like Al Qaeda to freely operate within its territory.

headline.main: Qatar’s Support of Islamists Alienates Allies Near and Far
headline.print_headline: Qatar’s Support of Extremists Alienates Allies Near and Far

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Mohamad Adam and Merna Thomas from Cairo, Isabel Kershner from Jerusalem and Fares Akram from Gaza.

docs.snippet: Krishna Upadhyaya, a researcher, and Ghimire Gundev, a photographer, had been reported missing on Aug. 31, that same day they were preparing to leave the country.”
docs.lead_paragraph: Krishna Upadhyaya, a researcher, and Ghimire Gundev, a photographer, had been reported missing on Aug. 31, that same day they were preparing to leave the country.”
docs.abstract: Authorities in Qatar confirm that British citizens Krishna Upadhyaya and Ghimire Gundev, who went missing while researching migrant labor issues, have been arrested and are being interrogated for having violated provisions of Qatari laws.

headline.main: Officials in Qatar Confirm Detention of Britons Researching Migrant Labor
headline.print_headline: Officials in Qatar Confirm Detention of Britons Researching Migrant Labor

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject

docs.snippet: Peter Theo Curtis was freed after extensive mediation by Qatar, which has negotiated the release of numerous Western hostages.
docs.lead_paragraph: Peter Theo Curtis was freed after extensive mediation by Qatar, which has negotiated the release of numerous Western hostages.
docs.abstract: American freelance writer Peter Theo Curtis is unexpectedly freed by the Nusra Front, Al Qaeda affiliate in Syria; release follows extensive mediation by Qatar, and raises further questions about what, if any, concessions should be made to militant groups holding Western nationals.

headline.seo: Peter Theo Curtis, Abducted in 2012, Is Released by Nusra Front
headline.main: U.S. Writer Held by Qaeda Affiliate in Syria Is Freed After Nearly 2 Years
headline.print_headline: Qaeda Affiliate Frees American It Held in Syria

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by C.J. Chivers from the United States, Rick Gladstone from New York, Michael R. Gordon from Washington, Ben Hubbard from Baghdad, and Karam Shoumali from Istanbul.

docs.snippet: The gulf nation began an ambitious program to identify and train talented boys from Africa as it sought to build its credibility as host of the 2022 World Cup.
docs.lead_paragraph: The gulf nation began an ambitious program to identify and train talented boys from Africa as it sought to build its credibility as host of the 2022 World Cup.
docs.abstract: Tiny gulf nation of Qatar, lacking enough young players to form national soccer team, began ambitious program to identify and train talent from Africa as it sought to build credibility as host of 2022 World Cup; Qatar says program is humanitarian venture, though there is some concern country may nationalize some of players (Series: Seeding the Field).

headline.main: Seeking Soccer Respect, Qatar Looked Abroad
headline.print_headline: Seeking Soccer Respect, Qatar Looked Abroad

byline.contributor: Steve Eder reported from Doha, Qatar; Sam Borden from Eupen, Belgium; and Christopher Harress and Jack Williams from New York.
byline.original: By STEVE EDER, SAM BORDEN, CHRISTOPHER HARRESS and JACK WILLIAMS

docs.snippet: In 2012, Aspire, bankrolled by Qatar’s royal family, acquired K.A.S. Eupen, a lower-division team in Belgium, as a place for its top players.
docs.lead_paragraph: In 2012, Aspire, bankrolled by Qatar’s royal family, acquired K.A.S. Eupen, a lower-division team in Belgium, as a place for its top players.

docs.snippet: Qatar’s lavish support of Hamas is the biggest obstacle to a deal on Gaza.
docs.lead_paragraph: Qatar’s lavish support of Hamas is the biggest obstacle to a deal on Gaza.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Ron Prosor, Israel's ambassador to the United Nations, holds Qatar's lavish support of Hamas represents the single biggest obstacle to a peace agreement in Gaza; contends the oil-rich gulf state has been using its vast wealth to leverage influence and destabilize rivals, choosing radical groups like Hamas as proxies; calls on global community to isolate Qatar until it revises its tactics.

docs.snippet: American forces took advantage of the strikes against the Islamic State in Syria to try to also wipe out the leadership of an unrelated cell that the White House said was plotting against the United States or Europe.
docs.lead_paragraph: American forces took advantage of the strikes against the Islamic State in Syria to try to also wipe out the leadership of an unrelated cell that the White House said was plotting against the United States or Europe.
docs.abstract: American forces take advantage of airstrikes against Islamic State extremist group in Syria to try and simultaneously wipe out leadership of Khorasan, unrelated cell of veterans of Al Qaeda; Obama administration says group was plotting 'imminent' attack against the United States or Europe.

headline.main: In Airstrikes, U.S. Targets Militant Cell Said to Plot an Attack Against the West
headline.print_headline: In Airstrikes, U.S. Targets Cell Said to Plot an Attack

docs.snippet: Secretary of State John Kerry asked the two nations to use their influence after the abduction, which took place shortly after a cease-fire was to go into effect.
docs.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry asked the two nations to use their influence after the abduction, which took place shortly after a cease-fire was to go into effect.

headline.main: Kerry Calls on Qatar and Turkey to Gain Release of Israeli Soldier

docs.snippet: Peter Theo Curtis, who had been held captive for nearly two years by the Nusra Front, was released after the government of Qatar intervened on his behalf, his family said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Peter Theo Curtis, who had been held captive for nearly two years by the Nusra Front, was released after the government of Qatar intervened on his behalf, his family said.
docs.abstract: Peter Theo Curtis, American writer and freelance journalist held captive for nearly two years by Al Qaeda’s official branch in Syria, returns to the United States after the government of Qatar brokers his release

headline.main: Peter Theo Curtis, Released by Al Qaeda’s Syrian Branch, Flies Home to His Family
headline.print_headline: American Journalist, Released by Al Qaeda’s Syrian Branch, Flies Home to His Family
